LinkedIn Attempts to Yoink Your Data

Author: êï£ C M D R ‚ñë NOVA êï£
Published: 19 Sep 2024


If you haven‚Äôt heard by now, LinkedIn suddenly implemented a ‚Äúfeature‚Äù into their social network that automatically opts you into allowing them to use all of your data for AI training. To top it off, they‚Äôve done this before altering their terms of service. So, technically, nobody‚Äôs agreed to this. But! We all know the people behind large learning models absolutely do not know what consent is.

Real quick, how to turn it off:

Click ‚ÄúMe‚Äù at the top, then go to ‚ÄúSettings and Privacy,‚Äù then click the ‚ÄúData Privacy‚Äù tab. I want to note how hilarious it is to have a tab called ‚ÄúData Privacy‚Äù where they‚Äôre automatically taking all of your data to sell to the highest bidder, and to feed into Microsoft‚Äôs plagiarism machines. But anyway ‚Ä¶ then click, ‚ÄúData for Generative AI Improvement,‚Äù and then toggle that off.

Problem solved!

But, honestly? Who the heck uses LinkedIn? The last time I seriously attempted to use the site as a social network, I felt like I should‚Äôve been compensated for my time, you know, paid. I felt like I should‚Äôve gone to work the next day and filled out a time adjustment just for logging into the Founder Zone.

Surely there‚Äôs a better way to go about advertising what you can do and who you are to the world, where your thoughts can stream independently and not be Zucked up by some kind of machine that‚Äôs melting the ice caps, right?

Everything you can do on LinkedIn, you can accomplish by building a portfolio, having a resume, and posting on normal social media regularly by sometimes showcasing your skills, and asking about job opportunities. This happens on the fediverse all of the time. Yes, I am once again suggesting you Join Mastodon.

You don‚Äôt need a social network where everyone is talking in customer service voice and never allowing their minds a break from work-life.

And, I mean, for sure, it goes without saying ‚Ä¶

Microsoft‚Äôs version of AI is pretty inescapable, despite measures I‚Äôve taken by ‚Ä¶ using Linux on my main machine, having an iPhone (which will now have an opt-in AI feature), and shelving my Xbox. But, this website is also fed through Github in order to be built, and deployed, and I do still keep some old files on Microsoft‚Äôs cloud drive.

Whichever way you look at it, you‚Äôve already been scraped by billionaires who should have paid you for your time, energy, and data. And, maybe someday they‚Äôll be forced to.

But that doesn‚Äôt mean you should subject yourself to LinkedIn, and allow Microsoft to take even more of your data. In the open web, I call that self harm.
